title: Anger Over Debate Fills Iowa Republican Forum
content:
“ Rubio has the most room to grow , ” said Tyler De Haan , the chairman of the Dallas County Republican Party , who was in the audience . “ He ’ s yet to hit his potential . The question is does he ride that run and at the right time ? You ’ ve got to get hot at the right time . ”
Jeb Bush said he did not know if his campaign would send representatives to the debate meeting , though he acknowledged he needed to improve his own debate performance .
“ I know I have to get better ; I have enough self-awareness , ” Mr. Bush told reporters after a stump speech that was more rousing and confident than his performance on the debate stage . Fighting to persuade Iowans , and especially the state ’ s many social conservatives , to take a closer look at him , Mr. Bush said that as Florida governor he pulled funding from Planned Parenthood ; fought to keep Terri Schiavo , a woman in a vegetative state , on life support against her husband ’ s wishes ; and made Florida the first state with a “ choose life ” license plate .
He also repeated the charge he had made against Mr. Rubio in the debate for missing Senate votes , which had set up a stinging rejoinder from Mr. Rubio on Wednesday . “ If you ’ re elected to serve , you should do what Chuck Grassley does , ” Mr. Bush said , referring to Iowa ’ s senior Republican senator . “ You should show up and vote . ”
The event was held at the state fairgrounds , where candidates courted supporters with Halloween-themed booths of carved pumpkins and pails of Tootsie Rolls . Mr. Bush ’ s state director wore pink bunny ears .
Looking over a Christie booth , Bob Myers , a retiree from Adel , Iowa , said he was making up his mind from among Mr. Christie , Mr. Rubio and Gov . John R. Kasich of Ohio . “ You need somebody who is tough enough to do the job and can basically slam their fist down and get things done , ” he said .
content_original:
“Rubio has the most room to grow,” said Tyler De Haan, the chairman of the Dallas County Republican Party, who was in the audience. “He’s yet to hit his potential. The question is does he ride that run and at the right time? You’ve got to get hot at the right time.”

Jeb Bush said he did not know if his campaign would send representatives to the debate meeting, though he acknowledged he needed to improve his own debate performance.

“I know I have to get better; I have enough self-awareness,” Mr. Bush told reporters after a stump speech that was more rousing and confident than his performance on the debate stage. Fighting to persuade Iowans, and especially the state’s many social conservatives, to take a closer look at him, Mr. Bush said that as Florida governor he pulled funding from Planned Parenthood; fought to keep Terri Schiavo, a woman in a vegetative state, on life support against her husband’s wishes; and made Florida the first state with a “choose life” license plate.

He also repeated the charge he had made against Mr. Rubio in the debate for missing Senate votes, which had set up a stinging rejoinder from Mr. Rubio on Wednesday. “If you’re elected to serve, you should do what Chuck Grassley does,” Mr. Bush said, referring to Iowa’s senior Republican senator. “You should show up and vote.”

The event was held at the state fairgrounds, where candidates courted supporters with Halloween-themed booths of carved pumpkins and pails of Tootsie Rolls. Mr. Bush’s state director wore pink bunny ears.

Looking over a Christie booth, Bob Myers, a retiree from Adel, Iowa, said he was making up his mind from among Mr. Christie, Mr. Rubio and Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio. “You need somebody who is tough enough to do the job and can basically slam their fist down and get things done,” he said.
